loans.use: to buy more breads, eggs, canned goods, laundry soaps, beverages, seasonings, frozen foods and soft drinks to resell

loans.name: Jinane

texts.en: Jinane is a 27-year-old married woman from Lebanon who lives with her husband and only child that attends school. Her husband works in the construction field and she works in producing homemade food. She combined forces with her husband to handle the high living expenses. At this time, Jinane wants to borrow a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to purchase items needed such as jar containers, etc.  Jinane declares that this Kiva loan will unquestionably bolster her sales and revenues.

loans.use: to purchase items needed such as jar containers, etc.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself as ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells salt, sugar, bread and other items. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in an area with potential and her primary customers are daily customers. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital. She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of salt, sugar, bread and other items. Her business goal is to expand to a supermarket within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will create employment for the youth. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock of salt, sugar, bread and other items

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is 42 years old, married to John and blessed with four children aged between 21 and 1 year old. She has been in the tailoring business for the last seven years and earns a monthly income of 35,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

She has applied for her fourth loan of 60,000 KES from VisionFund Kenya and intends to use the loan amount to buy more fabric material for making dresses. She paid back her previous loan successfully.

Tabitha will use the anticipated profits to provide for the family's basic needs. She hopes to grow her business and open another shop.

loans.use: to buy more fabric material  for making dresses

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy is a married woman with two children. She is 28 years old and both of her children are in school.

Juvy is a very hardworking entrepreneur, and she has a fishing business in the Philippines. Juvy requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to buy a new engine for her fishing boat. She has been in this business for five years. In the future, Juvy would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Rosemarie requested a 25,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase fishing materials like a net, gasoline, wood, etc. She has been in this business for three years now, and in the future, Rosemarie would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials like a net, gasoline, wood, etc.

loans.name: Hayfa

texts.en:
Hayfa is a 33-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She has two children and works really hard in cooperation with her husband to satisfy their needs. She works at producing Lebanese traditional homemade food. Her groceries are prepared well and sold out to many neighboring customers. 

And today, she is requesting to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to purchase supplies needed such as pots, containers and special bags to continue her work properly. Hayfa’s intention is to keep up her good work to direct her income rate to a greater extent.

loans.use: to purchase supplies needed such as pots, containers and special bags

loans.name: Kawkab

texts.en:
Kawkab is a 29-year-old Lebanese single woman. She works from her home in producing souvenir articles and items. She is very talented at her job and creates very unique designs for special occasions and events. 

Presently, she wants to borrow a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to purchase supplies needed to continue producing exceptional and inimitable pieces. Kawkab is a very positive person and a motivated one who always looks forward for more enhancements in her life.

loans.use: to purchase supplies

loans.name: Mame Ngone's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe crée depuis le 22 octobre 2007 est composé de quatre femmes issues du même quartier unies par de bonnes relations économiques et sociales.
La responsable madam Mame Ngoné est une femme mariée âgée de 39 ans et mère de enfants dont un garçon et une fille tous deux scolarisés. 
Actuellement elle s 'active dans le commerce d produits de beauté avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter des paquets de greffages et produits de beauté composé de lait de toilettes et de parfums qu'elle va revendre au détail au niveau de son quartier et du banc villageois. Les bénéfices réalisés lui permettent de prendre en charge les besoins alimentaires et scolaires d ses enfants et de rnforcer ses epargnes au niveau du banc villageois.
texts.en:
This group was created on October 22, 2007. It is composed of four women who are all from the same neighborhood and share healthy social and economic bonds. 
The group leader, Mrs. Mame Ngoné, is 39, married, and has several children, including a boy and a girl who both go to school. 
She is currently involved in cosmetics retail business. With this new loan, she will buy bags of hair weaves and other beauty products such as lotions and perfumes, which she will retail, both in her neighborhood and to some banc villageois members. The profits will enable her to feed her children and take care of their school fees, as well as to consolidate her savings with the banc villageois.

loans.use: to buy hair weaves and cosmetics in order to generate income

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a married man. He has one child. He describes himself as ambitious. He operates a transport business where he transports sand and building stones to customers using his lorry. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in an area with potential. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital. He will use the KES 90,000 loan to buy an engine for his lorry and pay for servicing. His business goal is to expand within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will create employment. This is his fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy an engine for his lorry and pay for servicing

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be optimistic. She operates a retail business where she sells onions. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a vibrant location and her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of onions. Her business goal is to own a tuk tuk within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of onions

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is 45-years-old and married with two children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase canned goods, egg, milk, coffee, etc.

Thelma has borrowed and paid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from farming rice.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, eggs, milk, coffee, etc.

loans.name: Maria Myrna

texts.en:
Maria Myrna is 48 years old and married with one child who is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Maria Myrna has a fishing business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for three years. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

In the future, Maria Myrna would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Vergenita

texts.en:
Vergenita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a grinding service business in the Philippines. Vergenita has been in this business for 20 years now.

She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy a new grinding machine and rice for grinding service.

In the future, Vergenita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy a new grinding machine and rice for grinding service

loans.name: Armeda

texts.en:
Armeda lives in Kapan city of the Syunik region with her single son and beloved husband. Both Armeda and her husband work at the machinery factory. Armeda works as a crane operator and her husband works as a locksmith. Her husband also repairs cars in a rented garage after his work. Despite the whole family being employed, they still did not manage to save enough money to help them to organize their son’s wedding party as nice as they would like.

This loan Armeda greatly needs in order to organize her son’s wedding and to buy nice gifts for her son and her future daughter-in-law. Armeda says that she dreams of her son’s wedding day, which she imagines will be unforgettable, nice and joyful.

loans.use: to organize her son’s wedding party and to buy nice gifts for her son and her future daughter-in-law

loans.name: Narine

texts.en:
Narine is 49 years old and she lives with her family in Vanadzor city of the Lori region. She is married, but now she lives with her retired parents since her husband is abroad, and her two children are already married and live separately with their families. 

Narine has no higher education and to earn money for a living, she had to try different work in different fields. Finally, she established her small trading business. In a rented stall at the city wholesale market, she sells sausages, olives in cans, and poultry meat. She buys all of these products from distributors several times a week. She says she has a lot of regular customers who have already been visiting her stall for 10 years to do their shopping. Narine makes sure that all the products are fresh, pure and not very expensive. 

Narine asks for this loan in an amount of 500,000 Armenian drams in order to expand her stall’s assortment with new products of sausages and olives.

loans.use: to expand her stall’s assortment with new products of sausages and olives.

loans.name: Hajar

texts.en: Hajar is a 22-year-old Lebanese single woman who is living with her parents. Her father is the main income provider for the family. Two years ago, she took the initiative and started her own business which consists of producing homemade food. Hajar made that decision since she wanted to supplement her family’s income and enhance their way of living. Today, she seeks to gain more profits, and to do so, she is asking to borrow a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase needed provisions to increase her output. Hajar is an optimistic person who seeks for more improvement in her personal and professional life.

loans.use: to purchase needed provisions.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is a single young man, born in 1992. He left school at the intermediate level to help in covering his family’s living expenses and needs for six other people. Although he left school at the intermediate level, he started working for a dairy products company, and with his eagerness, ambition, and intelligence, he was able to become a storekeeper. 

Now, Khaled is acquiring a youth Loan from Kiva’s field partner Al Majmoua to carry out his plans for the future, which starts by buying a car. He will then build his own house and make a family. This loan will help Khaled achieve his plans for the future and improve his social and financial situations.

loans.use: to buy a car necessary for facilitating his transportation needs.

loans.name: Heide

texts.en:
Heide is a married woman and the mother of four grown-up children from Leyte, Philippines.

She and her husband work in the transportation business and they own a passenger jeep. They have been in this business for more than 10 years now. Heidi is asking for a loan to buy spare parts for the jeep, including wheel tires, nuts and bolts, and gasoline. With this, she and her husband will be able to transport more passengers, and thus increase their income.

In the future, Heidi hopes to make their business a success.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the jeep, including wheel tires, nuts and bolts, and gasoline

loans.name: Isaiah

texts.en:
Isaiah is a married man and he has 2 children. He describes himself to be honest and ambitious.

He operates a retail business where he sells sugar, milk, bread and other items. He has been involved in this business for 3 years. His business is located in a business-friendly area and his primary customers are loyal. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances.

He will use the 60,000 KES loan to buy more stock of sugar, milk, bread and other items. His business goal is to have a business that yields high returns within 5 years. He hopes that, in the future, he will buy a home. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, milk, bread and other items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of cereals

loans.name: Mohamad Ali

texts.en: Mohamad is a 19-year-old Lebanese single man. He had to start working at a very young age with the aim of helping his parents increase the family’s income to live in better conditions. He is specialized in repairing air conditioners and works independently. Today, he is requesting to borrow a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase special machinery that will fill out the air conditioners with needed gas. Mohamad states that this mechanism will absolutely help him take on more projects and therefore help him receive higher revenue.

loans.use: to purchase special machinery.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is a married woman with five children. She is 36 years old and all of her children are in school.

Margarita is a very hardworking entrepreneur, and she has a dry goods business in the Philippines. She requested a 22,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to purchase more items like home products, toys and other ready-to-wear clothing.

Margarita has been in this business for twelve years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to school and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items like home products, toys and other ready-to-wear clothing.

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah's group is comprised of 2 hardworking women. 

Sarah is 23 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, she has been working hard to manage her carpentry business, which makes chairs. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more timber for the business, and will help her to generate greater profits and to buy food for her family. She hopes that in the future she will be able to start a new business. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more timber for her carpentry business

loans.name: Fatou's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de 26 femmes fait parti du banc villageois qui a été créé le 16 décembre 2013. Il est composé de membres qui vivent dans la même localité. Les membres sont solidaires et ont comme activités génératrices de revenus : le commerce.
Khoudia, la  vedette du groupe est à droite de la photo et a levé la main pour se faire distinguer. Elle est âgée de 34 ans, mariée et mère de 01 fille  et 03garçon. 
Elle envisage de faire du commerce de produits de détergents.
Elle va acheter un sac de savon en poudre à 8000f pour le revendre à 12000f ; un paquet de savon à 4000f qui va lui revenir à 5000f ; un paquet de savon liquide de 12 bouteilles à 8000r pour le revendre à 9000f
Les bénéfices servent à soutenir la famille en renforçant la dépense quotidienne et prenant en charge les besoins des enfants.
texts.en:
This group of 26 women is part of a banc villageois which was created on December 16, 2013. It is composed of members who all live in the same area. 
This is a solidarity loan. The members of this group generate their income through retail. Khoudia, the group's featured borrower, can be seen raising her hand, on the right hand side of the photo. She is 34, married, and the mother of one girl and three boys. She plans on buying and selling detergents. She is going to buy a bag of washing powder for 8000 XOF and resell it for 12000 XOF ; a 4000 XOF pack of washing powder which will resell for 5000 XOF; a 8000 XOF pack of 12 bottles of liquid detergent which she will resell for 9000 XOF. The profits will help her support her family by covering daily expenses and taking care of her children's needs.

loans.use: to buy detergents

loans.name: Roweida

texts.en:
Roweida is a 37-year-old Lebanese married woman living with her husband and only child.

She is a gifted person who portrays and illustrates special engineering drawings. She works on a freelance basis and sticks with projects and individuals to get their work done.

Presently, she seeks to arrange a special room at her house where she can proceed with her work properly and purchase needed design instruments. In that way, she will be able to improve her work by becoming more efficient and resourceful. In the future, Roweida wishes to borrow additional Kiva loans to continue developing her work.

loans.use: to arrange a special room at her house and purchase needed design instruments

loans.name: Erick

texts.en: Erick is a single man, and he describes himself to be determined. He operates a transportation business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a vibrant area and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. He will use the 50,000 KES loan to buy another motorcycle. His business goal is to own a tuk tuk within five years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance  Bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 30,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell at her business.

Vilma has been in this business for 10 years, and she earns additional income from culturing fish. She sustains her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Vivilyn

texts.en:
Vivilyn is 33 years old with one child.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 23,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. Vivilyn has borrowed and repaid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 8 years and also earns an income from buying and selling ready to wear clothing.

She aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Ilaha

texts.en:
Ilaha is 27 years old. She has been married for over 4 years and has a child who is a 2-year-old boy.

They are living in Horadiz village in Fuzuli region, but the family members are Internally Displaced Persons from Fuzuli city. Her mother-in-law helps her to educate and take care of children, and Ilaha works in the store. This store was opened by Ilaha and her husband 3 years ago.

Today Ilaha wants to support the family business and for that she needs a loan in amount of 2,000 Azerbaijani New Manat. With this amount, Ilaha wants to buy more goods to sell so she can develop her business and increase their monthly income. Ilaha wishes the best for her child and she works hard. She says a deep thank you to the Kiva organization for their big support.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Maximilla

texts.en:
Maximilla is 30 years old and married to Benedict, and they are blessed with two children aged nine and six years old. 

She has been selling fresh tomatoes and onions for the last five years and earns a monthly income of KES 4,500.
	 
She has now applied for her second loan of KES 7,500 from VisionFund Kenya and intends to use the loan amount to buy more tomatoes and onions to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to buy more stock of tomatoes and onions. 

She hopes to grow her business and open a wholesale shop in the future to supply farm produce.

loans.use: to buy more tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Oscar Armando

texts.es: Don Oscar, tiene su negocio ubicado en una zona comercial de alto transito, y ofrece una gran variedad de prendas de vestir (blusas, vestidos, pantalones, camisas) y ademas comercializa perfumeria y carteras de bajo costo, que son accesibles a su segmento de mercado. En la fotografia se puede observar a Don Oscar, posando junto a su mercaderia. el pide apoyo para incrementar su inventario, dada la cercania de las fiestas, para los que sus clientes demandan nuevos estilos.
texts.en:
Oscar's business is located in a high-traffic commercial zone.  He offers a large variety of garments (blouses, dresses, pants, shirts) and he also sells perfume and low-cost handbags that are accessible to his segment of the market. 

In the photograph, Oscar can be seen posing next to his merchandise. He is requesting support in order to increase his inventory, as his customers are demanding new styles for the approaching holidays.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to stock his shop

loans.name: Obed

texts.en:
Obed is a married man who describes himself as ambitious. 

He operates a retail business where he sells livestock, and he has been involved in this business for 5 years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are individual buyers. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more livestock. 

His business goal is to be a large supplier of livestock within 5 years, and he hopes that in the future he will be successful. 

This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: To buy more livestock

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 33-year-old widow who has been blessed with two children.  

For the past 4 years she has been running a poultry rearing business alongside farming as a secondary business, earning an income of KES 14,000 per month.
 
Mary was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a credit officer and is now taking out her first loan of KES 30,000. She intends to use the entire amount to buy additional hens and poultry feeds to add to her stock, which is running out.

She plans to use the anticipated income to start a dairy farming business and hopes to become a successful business woman.

loans.use: To buy additional hens and feeds for her poultry farm.

loans.name: Ma. Chona

texts.en:
Ma. Chona is a married woman and a mother of two young children from Leyte, Philippines. Ma. Chona runs a sari-sari or variety store business selling various goods and items to the people in her place. Several months ago, Ma. Chona's business was ruined when a typhoon hit the country.

Ma. Chona is now asking for a loan to buy more stock to sell, such as canned goods, candies, biscuits and chips, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, cooking seasoning and others. With this, she will be able to augment her stock, thus attracting more buyers in her store. 

In the future, Ma. Chona hopes to make her business a success. Furthermore, she wants to save money for future schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell, such as canned goods, candies, biscuits and chips, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, cooking seasoning and others.

loans.name: Awa's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de 31 femmes fait parti du banc villageois qui a été créé le 16 décembre 2013. Il est composé de membres qui vivent dans la même localité. Les membres sont solidaires et ont comme activités génératrices de revenus : le commerce.
Astou debout sur la photo et levant la main, est âgée de 35 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 filles. 
Elle envisage de faire de la couture. Elle achète 7 draps à 3500f l’unité, du fil 3 paquets à 4500f, elle paye 14000f pour qu’on lui fasse des destins sur les draps. Une fois les draps cousus elle les vend à 15000f chacun.
Avec les bénéfices elle va acheter du bois et du charbon pour les revendre. Elle prend aussi en charge les frais scolaires  de ses enfants et renforcer la dépense quotidienne.
texts.en:
This group of 31 women is part of a banc villageois which was created on December 16, 2013. 
It is composed of members who all live in the same area. 
This is a solidarity loan. The members of this group generate their income through retail. Astou, who can be seen on the photo standing up and raising her hand, is 35. She is married and is the mother of five daughters. 
She plans on sewing. She will buy 7 sheets for 3500 XOF each, 3 packs of yarn for 4500 XOF, and will pay 14,000 XOF to have designs printed on the sheets. Once the sheets are sewn, she will sell them for 15,000 XOF each. 
With the profits, she will buy wood and charcoal in order to resell them. This will also help with daily expenses and enable her to care of her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy sheets and some yarn

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself to be dedicated. 

She operates a tailoring business where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a good area, and her primary customers are individuals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more tailoring materials. 

She hopes that in the future, she will be a successful business lady. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more tailoring materials.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is 18 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past year, Deborah has been working hard to manage her small retail business, which sells cooking oil. 

To help expand her business, Deborah has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more jerrycans of cooking oil for sale, and will help Deborah to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her sister. Deborah hopes that in the future, she will be able to start up another business. 

Deborah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more jerrycans of cooking oil for sale.

loans.name: Lusine

texts.en:
Lusine is 40 years old and she lives in the village Syunik in Syunik region. Lusine is a very artistic person and she has a musical education. She graduated from the department of piano studies at Kapan State Musical College. As she says, she dreamed of working in her profession, but she never had such an offer or any chance to work at least as a piano teacher.

Anyway, she says she feels happy with her small family and their cute farm that she established with her husband many years ago. Lusine has a school-aged son, and her husband works at the local rescue service as a rescue man. Lusine’s main occupation is the care of her house and her farm. On her farm she has 5 cows, 2 heifers and 2 calves. So, from the main product of her farm, milk, she makes magnificently tasty cheese and butter, as well as macun (an Armenian national dairy product) to sell.  All of these items she sells to her numerous regular customers right from her farm.

Now, Lusine worries about the lack of fodder (feed) for her farm cattle, which she always begins to store beforehand.  She will use this loan for the purchase of fodder for her farm cattle.

loans.use: to purchase fodder for her farm cattle

loans.name: Aliyu

texts.en: Aliyu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Aliyu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Aliyu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Aliyu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Aliyu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Samaila joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Idi, Isah, and  Binta. Samaila is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Samaila will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Samaila can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Samaila is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Levon

texts.en:
Levon is 56 years old and lives in Kapan city, which is in Syunik region. Levon has higher pedagogical education and a specialty in philology. He is a specialist in Armenian Language and Literature. He has always worked in his field. For many years he worked as a teacher and, simultaneously, as director of the same school. He also worked at the Municipality as a head of the Educational Department. Levon is a very intellectual and clever person who, despite his age, still continues to study. He is aware of innovations that have occurred in his pedagogical field. 

Now Levon is a director of the school in Kapan city, and he also gives paid private courses in Armenian Language and Literature. Levon lives with his wife, who is also a teacher. She works at the kindergarten. Their children are already married, and they live with their families abroad. 

This will be Levon’s first deal with Kiva, and he is sure it will be successful. He has heard about Kiva’s great hospitality toward all people who have any kind of need, and especially toward pedagogues and teachers. Teachers direct the new generation to create our future, which must be based on wisdom and intelligence of society.

Levon would like to use this loan to buy a computer and some professional literature, which will be useful in both of his occupations.

loans.use: to buy a computer and some professional literature

loans.name: Riga

texts.en: Riga is a Babban Gona farmer from Kiyawa. Riga expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Riga to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Riga can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Riga, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Riga will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Riga will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.name: Arirah

texts.en:
Arirah's group is comprised of  hard working women. Arirah is 16 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past year, Arirah has been working hard to manage her small local brewing business, which sells the local drink. 

To help expand her business, Arirah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy millet that will be used to make the local drink, this will help Arirah to generate greater profits and pay rent for the working place of the business. Arirah hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a bar. 

Arirah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy millet that will be used to make the local drink.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is 23 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past three years, Farida has been working hard to manage her small fish business, where she sells small silver fish.

To help expand her business, Farida has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more silver fish to sell, and will help Farida to generate greater profits and take care of her family's basic needs. Farida hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house.

Farida is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more silver fish to sell

loans.name: Maty's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de la localité inauguré le 28 septembre 2012. Il est composé de vingt cinq femmes qui habitent le village et ses environs. Certaines d'entre elles viennent d'un petit village qui se trouve à 3 km du lieu de rencontre. Les principales activités sont l'agriculture, l'élevage et le petit commerce.


Madame Mboulé la représentante est âgée de 34 ans. Elle est mariée mère de trois enfants dont un garçon.Elle s'active dans l'élevage ovine et fait aussi parallèlement du petit commerce de beignets et d'oranges. Elle a une bonne expérience de plus de 15 ans.Elle est sur la photo à droite à l'extrême la main levée.


Avec son prêt elle compte acheter deux moutons à 20000 F l'un pour faire de l'embouche ovine. Elle vend des beignets et des oranges au marché du village; elle n'est pas la seule à faire cette activité.

Avec les bénéfices obtenus elle va subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants et renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
This group is part of a local banc villageois which was created on September 28, 2012. It is composed of 25 women who live in the village and its surroundings. Some of them are from a village located 3km away from the group's meeting spot. Their main activities are agriculture, sheep farming, and petty trade.

Mrs. Mboulé, the group's representative, is 34. She is married and is the mother of four children, one of whom is is a boy. She is into sheep farming and also sells doughnuts and oranges on the side. She has been successfully working in this field for over 15 years. She can be seen on the far right of the photo, raising her hand.

With this loan, she plans on buying two sheep at 20,000 XOF each, for sheep fattening. She sells doughnuts and oranges at the village market; she is not the only one running this sort of business.

The profits will enable her to meet her children's needs and consolidate her savings.

loans.use: to buy sheep for fattening.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a married man. He has six children. He describes himself as business oriented. He operates a chemist where he sells medicine. He has been involved in this business for seven years. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of medicine. His business goal is to have a bigger shop within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of medicine

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane is a married woman and a mother of three children. She lives in Leyte, Philippines. Mary Jane and her husband have been engaged in a fishing business for several years now. This is the source of their income. Last year, their fishing boat was ruined by Typhoon Haiyan and, with that, their income decreased drastically. At the moment, they are asking for a loan to buy additional materials for the repair of their fishing boat, like plywood, nails, paint, and other items. When their boat is repaired, her husband will be able to go back to fishing and increase his catch, thus giving them more fish to sell in the market.

loans.use: to buy additional materials for the repair of her fishing boat

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a married man. He has five children. He describes himself as determined. He operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for four years. His primary customers are individuals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy motorcycle spare parts to sell. His business goal is to own a large motorcycle spare parts shop within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP Micro-finance Bank.

loans.use: to buy motorcycle spare parts to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Dauda

texts.en: Dauda is a Babban Gona farmer from Kiyawa. Dauda expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Dauda to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Dauda can reap up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. By doing so, Dauda will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Dauda will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a Babban Gona farmer. Hassan is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Hassan to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hassan can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Hassan, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season, because with this loan, he will finally be able to access required yield enhancing inputs, such as improved seeds. Hassan is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland". With this loan, Hassan will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ndeye Faly's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de la localité inauguré le 28 septembre 2012. Il est composé de vingt cinq femmes qui habitent le village et ses environs. Certaines d'entre elles viennent d'un petit village qui se trouve à 3 km du lieu de rencontre. Les principales activités sont l'agriculture, l'élevage et le petit commerce.


Madame Ndéye Faly la représentante est âgée de 52 ans. Elle est mariée mère de 7 enfants dont 2 sont mariés. Elle est grand mère de 6 petits enfants : 4 garçons et 2 filles. Elle s'active dans l'élevage ovine et fait aussi parallèlement du petit commerce de poissons séchés et d'omo. Elle a une bonne expérience de 13 ans pour ces activités. Elle est sur la photo à droite à l'extrême la main levée.


Avec son prêt elle compte acheter un mouton à 40000 F , des poissons séchés à 7000 F et un sac d'omo à 8000 F. Elle est la seule à vendre de l'omo en grande quantité dans le village. Elle vend chez elle et au marché du village et elle a beaucoup de clients. 


Avec les bénéfices obtenus de ses activités elle va acheter deux petits moutons pour augmenter son troupeau;elle va participer aux dépenses de la famille en nourriture et la santé des enfants; et régler ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
This group is part of the local banc villageois, which was founded on September 28, 2012. It is comprised of 25 women who live in and around the village. Some of them live in a small village located three kilometers from their meeting spot. The group’s primary activities are agriculture, livestock farming, and small business.

Madame Ndéye Faly, the representative, is 52 years old. She is married and the mother of seven children, two of whom are married. She has six grandchildren, four boys and two girls. She works in sheep farming and also has a small business where she sells dried fish and Omo brand soap. She has 13 years of experience in these activities. She is pictured at right with her hand raised. 

With her loan, she would like to buy a sheep for 40,000 F, dried fish for 7,000 F, and a bag of Omo soap for 8,000 F. She is the only one in the village to sell Omo in any significant quantity. She sells out of her home and in the village market where she has many clients. 

With the profits earned from her businesses, she will buy two small sheep to increase her flock. She will also share in the family expenses (food and healthcare for the children) and take care of her own needs.

loans.use: to buy sheep for livestock farming.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to raise chickens.

Douglas will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stocks of rice. His business goal is to be the best within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will raise the living standards of his family. This is his first loan with SMEP Micro-finance Bank.

loans.name: Alh. Ali

texts.en: Alh. Ali is a 45-year-old farmer from Kartau.  As a Babban Gona member, Alh. Ali is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alh. Ali can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Alh. Ali is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Alh. Ali is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Ibrahim,  and  Hashimu. Alh. Ali’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Jacqcline

texts.en:
Jacqcline is a 30-year-old woman married to Januaries, who adds additional income to support the welfare of their family. They are blessed with one child. Jacqcline has been a farmer for four years, earning an income of KES 15,000 at the end of every month.

Jacqcline was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a friend and is now servicing her first loan of KES 20,000 and intends to use the whole amount to buy fertilizer and seedlings for her farm plantation.

Jacqcline plans to use the anticipated income to add some food stock to their family business shop, which is operated by her husband, and hopes to have a bright future as well as to start a rental business in the near future.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings for her farm plantation.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en: Tomas is a 46-year-old farmer from Gangara.  As a Babban Gona member, Tomas is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Tomas can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Tomas is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Tomas is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Jibril, and  Alheri. Tomas’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Maria Dolores

texts.es: Doña Maria Dolores, tiene una tienda surtida de artículos de primera necesidad, que vende principalmente a las personas que visitan la escuela principal del caserío, por lo que su rotación de inventarios es muy buena. su grupo familiar lo compone su cónyuge e hijos. En la fotografía se puede observar a Doña Maria Dolores junto a su inventario (mercadería) que ofrece a sus clientes. Ella solicita financiamiento para incrementar el inventario.
texts.en: Maria Dolores has a store stocked with basic goods that she sells primarily to people who visit the primary school in her community, so her stock is constantly changing. Her family consists of her husband and children. In the photograph, one can see Maria Dolores with her merchandise that she offers to her clients. She is applying for the loan in order to increase their inventory.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Jamira's Group

texts.en:
Jamira's group is comprised of two hard working women. Jamira is 16 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa, in the Lganga region of Uganda. For the past year, Jamira has worked hard to manage her business, which sells new clothes. 

To expand her business, Jamira has requested a loan of 400000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase for new clothes for sale, and will help Jamira generate greater profits and go back to school and pay her tuition fee. Jamira hopes to start a new business of selling shoes. 

Jamira is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a form life-skills through training.

loans.use: to purchase new clothes to sell.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a married man who has eight children.  He describes himself as honest. 

James operates a motor vehicle repair business and has been doing this work for10 years. His primary customers are regulars.  

He describes his biggest business challenge to be insecurity.  He will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy vehicle paint.  

His business goal is to be the best within five years.  James hopes to raise the living standard of his family. 

This is James' fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.  Previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy vehicle paint.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a married man with three children. He operates a retail business where he sells clothes and has been in business for six years. 

His business is located in urban area and his primary customers are men. 

James will use the Kes 98,000 loan to buy more clothes. He hopes that in the future, he will be victorious. 

This is James' third loan with SMEP microfinance bank.  Previous loans were repaid successfully. 

He will use the anticipated profits to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy calves, raise and sell them.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Hello!  Meet Francis, a very hardworking, industrious and visionary farmer who is 51 years of age.  He hails from the Kisii area of Kenya, an area referred to as a banana growing region, and the staple food is "matoke."

He has a wife are blessed with eight children whom he really loves.  He has been practicing mixed farming for the past five years and through those years he has gained much experience. 

His primary source of income has been milk, egg and crop farming.  Of all the activities he is involved in, dairy farming is what he enjoys and is close to his heart.  And because of this he has even nicknamed one of his cow ”mochama” (from a person’s name).  

Francis is seeking a loan to buy a quality dairy cow.  Dairy farming is a very profitable agriculture venture in Kenya and dairy businesses have seen an upsurge in growth and milk prices have gone up. 

Francis is sure that through the loan, he will make more profits from selling milk.  Francis does not worry about the market because he will be selling milk directly to the market and to big dairy processing firms.

Through the loan, Francis will not only benefit from profits from milk selling but from manure from the dairy cow and hence increase productivity on his farm. 

Money will be saved because he will not have to buy manure and hence the money will be used to improve his living conditions.

Francis is very visionary and hopes to increase his business by packaging milk and products such as yogurt. 

Through increased income he will permanently change his life and assure that his children will receive a good education.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

texts.en: Alhaji is a Babban Gona farmer from Ikara. Alhaji is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is this ambition that led Alhaji to join Babban Gona. Like all Babban Gona members, Alhaji can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.
