However, Alhaji, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season, because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Alhaji is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Alhaji will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Sector La Unión 3 Group

texts.es:
Floridalma de 30 años de edad soltera con 1 hijo que es estudiante en su comunidad donde viven, ella a tratado la forma de cómo salir adelante con su hijo para que tenga la condición de vida que se merece, (Floridalma es la que se encuentra primero de derecha a izquierda la que esta vestida blusa negra con flores).

Ella trabaja en una institución pública donde pone sus servicios laborales para poder sustentar a su familia y así tener un ingreso económico para mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y ver crecer a su hijo y convertiré en un profesional del mañana para tener una mejor vida, que es lo único que le puede dejar como herencia a su hijo.

Ella se convirtió en un ejemplar mujer en su comunidad y es por ello que un grupo de mujeres se unió a ella para desempeñar sus actividad diarias para tener un futuro menor y vivir en condiciones de vidas agradables.

La inversión que ella le dará al préstamo es para la inversión de sus estudios para prepararse más académicamente. Uno de las metas de ella es ver a su hijo convertirse en un profesional en la vida y que tenga estudios universitarios y construir su casa para tener una condición de vida adecuada en el futuro.
texts.en:
Floridalma is 30 years old, single, and has one son who is a student in the community where they live. She has tried to find a way to get ahead in life with her son so that he can have the kind of life he deserves. (Floridalma is the first woman on the right who is wearing a black shirt with flowers). She works in a public institution where she labors to sustain her family and to have sufficient income to improve her family's standard of living. To allow her son to grow and to become a professional so that he may have a better life--this is all that she can give to him. 

She has become an exemplary woman in her community and this has encouraged this group of women to unite around her to carry out their daily tasks and create a better future where they can have a decent life. This loan will allow her to make an investment in her education in order to prepare herself better academically. One of her goals is to see her son become a professional with a university level education and to build a house so that they may have an adequate standard of living in the future.

loans.use: invest in education.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy three calves to fatten and sell at a better price

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 41 year old woman married to Jeremiah, who adds additional income to their family.  They are blessed with four children.  Elizabeth has been a farmer for four years, earning an income of KES 9,000 every month.

Elizabeth was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a credit officer.  She will use her first loan of KES.15 000 to purchase fertilizer,seedlings and cultivate her farm.

Elizabeth plans to use the anticipated income to buy a bigger farm and she hopes to start a livestock rearing business with a bright future.

loans.use: to cultivate her farm.  Buy seedlings and fertilizer.

loans.name: Fanny Lastenia

texts.es:
En la calle San Eduardo vía a Santa Ana de la ciudad de Portoviejo, conocida como la Ciudad de Los Reales Tamarindos desde épocas coloniales, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Grupo De Crédito 16 de Julio.
En este lugar vive la señora Fanny, tiene 49 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 24, 16 y 14 años, los dos menores estudian en colegio pero todos aun vive en su casa. Su esposo es chofer.
Doña Fanny con la intención de ganarse algo por su cuenta y con esto poder ayudarle a su marido a salir adelante en el hogar se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, zapatos y también ciertos víveres que vende en su casa,  su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su  casa donde tiene un pequeño local en el cual vende los víveres y aprovecha de vender su mercadería si sus clientes así lo quieren. Trabaja todos los días, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Tiene cinco años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar pantalones, blusas, camisetas y víveres para surtir su negocio. Está en el Grupo De Crédito desde hace  4 ciclos y le gusta porque los créditos son rápidos y sin tantos requisitos. Sus sueños tener una gran tienda.
texts.en:
Every 15 days the members of Grupo de Credito get together on San Eduardo street across from Santa Ana in the city of Portoviejo, known since colonial times as the Ciudad de Los Reales Tamarindos. Fanny, a 46 year old woman who is married with three children who are 24, 16 and 14 years old, lives in this place. Her two youngest children are in high school, but all three of them still live at home. Her husband is a driver. 

With the goal of earning something of her own, allowing her to help her husband and improve the home, Fanny began selling all types of clothing, shoes and food products from her home. She sells door to door and also from her home where she has a small shop from which she sells food and products like her customers want. She works every day, allowing her customers a credit that they pay off every 15 days. She has been working like this for five years and it has been going very well. With this loan, she will buy blouses, shirts and food to stock her business. She has been in the Grupo de Credito for four cycles and she likes it because the loans arrive quickly and there are few restrictions. Her dream is to one day own a large store.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, blouses and food.

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en:
Saodat is hardworking woman, born in 1967. She is married and has three children. Saodat is a careful mother for her children.  Her husband is a farmer. Their live poorly.

Saodat decided to start business to find another source of family income.  Saodat is going to start an animal husbandry business. 

Saodat took a course ‘To Get Ahead’.  She got a certificate.  Saodat will feed cattle in her house where she has a cowshed.  And her husband has promised to help her. 

She is asking for a loan of 600 Somoni to buy cattle.  She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy cattle and start a new business.

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en: Yahaya is a Babban Gona farmer from Shawai. Yahaya expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Yahaya to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yahaya can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yahaya is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Yahaya will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Yahaya will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: ta o buy new sewing machine and embroidery machine.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis who is a married man describes himself as focused.  He operates a farm where he keeps dairy cows which produce milk he sells. His business is located in a semi urban area and his primary customers are men and women. 

He describes his biggest business challenges as drought and animal diseases. 

Francis will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy cattle medicine and animal feed.  His business goal is to buy more cows within five years. 

Francis hopes that in the future, he will improve his life.

loans.use: to buy cattle medicine and animal feed.

loans.name: Haider

texts.en:
Haider is a 26 year-old, married and with two children.  He has nine years of experience selling women's clothes, cosmetics and accessories.  Haider sells good quality products and offers a variety of different brands.

Haider is taking this 3000 USD youth loan to buy more products and to renovate his workplace.  He aims to expand his store and line of products to stay competitive in the market.

The story of Haider and his business is one of many examples of Izdiharona for Economic Development's clients.

loans.use: to buy more products and renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase an air conditioner, generator and renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Ziyadah's Group

texts.en:
Ziyadah's group is comprised of 4 hard working women.  Ziyadah is 16 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda.  For the past year, Ziyadah has been working hard to manage her small fish business, which sells fresh fish. 

To help expand her business, Ziyadah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more fish to sell, and will help Ziyadah to generate greater profits and pay rent for the workspace of the business.  Ziyadah hopes that in the future she will be able to start up a restaurant. 

Ziyadah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Risper

texts.en: Risper is a married woman. She has four children. She operates a retail business where she sells tomatoes and other vegetables. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in a market area and her primary customers are locals. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of vegetables. She hopes that in the future, she will have an improved lifestyle. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of vegetables

loans.name: Madelis

texts.es: Madelis es comerciante de bolsos y billeteras traídos por su amiga de un país cercano a Colombia; ella  vende a crédito estos productos, trabajando diariamente de 8 a 6 de la tarde a una clientela que ella ha construido, desde el año 2009 cuando inició su negocio. A Madelis su amiga le propuso que fuera su distribuidora  y una vez aceptó, el éxito no se hizo esperar. En la actualidad compra de contado a mayoristas para venderle amigos referidos y vecinos del barrio donde habita. Su meta mas adelante es importar directamente la mercancía que sus clientes le solicitan, para ganar mas y en un futuro remodelar su vivienda. Su mayor desafió es fidelizar su clientela, con buenos precios buenos productos y buena atención. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará un mayor volumen de bolsos y billeteras, con el propósito de incrementar sus ventas y sus utilidades, mejorando así las condiciones de su negocio.
texts.en:
Madelis sells purses and wallets that her friend brings from a country near Colombia. She sells these products on credit, working daily from 8:00 to 6:00 in the evening, serving the customer base that she has been growing since she started this business in 2009. Her friend suggested that Madelis serve as a distributor and when she accepted, she did not expect such great success. Currently, she buys the products wholesale in cash to sell them to referred friends and neighbors in the neighborhood where she lives. 

Her future goal is to import the merchandise that her clients ask for directly so that she can earn more and remodel her home. Her greatest challenge is to create a loyal clientele with good products, prices and customer service. She is now applying to Credikiva, the first request she has made of the Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, with the goal of purchasing a larger quantity of purses and wallets so that she can increase her sales and offerings, thus improving her business.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity of purses and wallets.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married woman with 4 children.  For 5 years she has operated a retail business selling clothing.  Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals.  She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of funds.  

Rose will use the 35,000 KES loan to buy additional stock of clothing.  Her business goal is to own a large business within 5 years.  She hopes that in the future, she will be happy.  This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank, with the previous loan being repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of clothing.

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati appreciates the previous loan she got from Kiva. She has operated a retail shop business for the past three years, selling household consumables like wheat flour and maize flour from home to her neighbours. Bahati faces a challenge of delayed payments by creditors in her business. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the future.

With this Kshs 20,000,  Bahati wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca, a married mother of four, describes herself as honest. She has been selling fruits and vegetables for four years now, her business located in an area with potential. She describes her biggest challenge to be lack of funds. 

Rebecca will use this Kes 10,000 loan, her first with SMEP Microfinance Bank, to buy more stocks of fruits and vegetables. Her business goal is to expand within five years.

loans.use: buy more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Darlen

texts.es: Darlen vende productos de belleza y ropa desde hace 18 años; todo empezó cuando su amiga la impulsó, para que se afiliara al comercio mediante catálogos, Darlen  trabajaba en los comedores del colegio, y su amiga la guió para que mostrara a los profesores los artículos y ganara dinero vendiendo a crédito. Hoy su tarea continua, aunque tuvo un receso por haberse accidentado su hijo, lo cual fue un gran desafío de vida, pues debió gastar el capital de su negocio y volver a iniciar. Aun así, con esfuerzos, vende a crédito, trabajando desde las 3 de la tarde hasta las 7 de la noche, comprando directamente a almacenes de la ciudad, mediante guías especializadas de productos y vendiendo a una amplia clientela, entre las que se encuentran vecinos del barrio donde habita, familiares y referidos . Su meta es ampliar su negocio y tener un almacén bien surtido, para ganar más y darle una buena educación a su ultimo hijo, que se encuentra en la edad de 10 años. En la actualidad está aplicando a un  Credikiva, mediante el cual comprará ropa, productos de belleza, que han llegado en sus catálogos con buenos precios y quiere con ellos impactar sus ventas, sacandole mas provecho a su crédito, para mejorar aun mas su  negocio.
texts.en:
Darlen has been selling beauty products and clothes for the past 18 years. Everything started when her friend pushed her to affiliate herself with catalog retail. Darlen worked at a school cafeteria, and her friend urged her to show the teachers the products and earn money selling on credit.

Today, her business continues, although she took a break after her child was in an accident, which was a great life challenge because she had to spend the capital of her business and start over. Even then, with effort, she sells on credit, working from 3 in the afternoon until 7 at night. She buys directly from stores in the city using specialized product guides and sells to a large customer base, including neighbors from the town where she lives, family members, and referrals.

Her goal is to expand her business and to have a well-stocked store in order to earn more and to give a good education to her last child, who is 10 years old. She is currently requesting a Credikiva, which she will use to buy clothes and beauty products listed in her catalogs at good prices. She wishes to increase her sales, taking full advantage of her loan in order to continue improving her business.

loans.use: to buy clothes and beauty products.

loans.name: Barbra

texts.en:
Barbra is 16 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past year, Barbra has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Barbra has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock of fresh food to sell. This will help Barbra to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young brother. Barbra hopes that in the future she will be able to start another business. 

Barbra is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fresh food to sell

loans.name: Maria Vicenta

texts.es: Doña Maria Vicenta tiene un pequeño negocio en el que ofrece golosinas y bebidas desde hace 3 años, se encuentra ubicado en una zona de movimiento de escolares. su grupo familiar lo componen 2 hijos pequeños, a los que mantiene con las ganancias de su actividad. En la fotografia se puede observar parte de la mercaderia que ella comercializa y que desea incrementar para mejorar su oferta a su clientela, para lo cual pide el apoyo del credito
texts.en: Dona Maria Vicenta has had a small business for the past three years that sells candy and drinks. It is located in a school zone. Her family is made up of two small children, which she supports with the profits from her business. In the photograph you can see some of the merchandise that she sells and that she wishes to increase in order to improve her product offering for her clients, which requires the support of a loan.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her store

loans.name: Lillian

texts.en:
Lilian is 16 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past two years, she has been working hard to manage her small fish-selling business. 

To help expand her business, Lilian has requested a loan of 200000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to stock more baskets of fish for sale. This will help her to generate greater profits and buy food for the family. Lilian hopes that in the future she will be able to take care of her family and build a house for them. 

Lilian is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to stock more baskets of fish for sale

loans.name: Jumaa

texts.en:
Jumaa is a married man with six children, two of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither piped water nor electricity. 

Jumaa has operated a coconut business selling at the market to his local customers. He dreams of expanding his business in the future.

With the 20,000 KES loan, Jumaa wants to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz de 33 años de edad habita al suroccidente de la ciudad, con su esposo y sus tres hijos en las edades de 6 a 12 años. Desde el año 1999, Luz se dedica a mejorar la imagen personal y profesional de hombre, mujeres y niños, pues desde muy niña sintió gran atracción, por todas las actividades relacionadas con la belleza. Ella inició a los 14 años aprendiendo a hacer manicure y pedicure, posteriormente estudió técnicas de belleza que ha ido perfeccionando con su experiencia y hoy ofrece muchos servicios en un salón de bellezas; Sus principales productos de la oferta son cortes de cabello, peinados, blówers, tinturado aliser etc. Luz trabaja todos los días de la semana, desde las 10:30 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche, atendiendo a sus clientes del sector donde habita, lugar donde ya es muy reconocida. La meta principal de Luz, es ampliar su negocio y hacer mejoramiento a su vivienda mas adelante . En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo,  mediante el cual comprará un aire acondicionado, para mejorar la calidad del servicio, lo cual es un gran avance en el perfeccionamiento de su negocio.
texts.en:
Luz is 33 years of age and lives southwest of the city with her husband and 3 children of ages 6 and 12. Since 1999, Luz has made a living improving the personal and professional image of men, women, and children. Since she was a very little girl she has been greatly attracted to work related to beauty. She began at 14 years old learning to do manicures and pedicures. Later she studied beauty techniques which she has perfected with her experience. Today she offers many services in her beauty salon. Her main products offerings are haircuts, hairstyles, blow drys, hair dyes, etc. 

Luz works everyday of the week from 10:30 AM to 9 PM. She tends to her customers in the area where she lives, a place where she is already very well known. Luz's main goal is to expand her business and make improvements in her home much later. Currently she is applying for a first financing loan through Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. With this she will buy an air conditioner to improve the quality of service which will be a great advance in improving her business.

loans.use: to buy an air conditioner

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Kiva lenders! Meet Sarah, a 63-year-old, energetic and hardworking mother of two lovely children, who reside in Litein area of Kenya. This area experiences one of the good weather patterns that favour crop and animal farming. Sarah has been a farmer for the past 40 years and through the income, she has been able to take care of her family and parents, making sure that they have the basic needs. Due to the high unemployment rate in Kenya, Sarah could not find a job to support her family, but she didn’t surrender to that. She started farming, and through mixed farming she has been able to earn a decent income. 

Sarah is seeking a loan of KES 20,000 to buy poultry. Because of an increased market in poultry, Sarah wants to take advantage of that. Having an entrepreneurial mind, she cannot let this opportunity pass by. Profits generated from egg selling and poultry product selling will be used to repay the loan, and also to assist her family and the community. Sarah intends to use the income generated to improve her living conditions, and to impact the society positively. Sarah is hoping for your kindness.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Beth

texts.en:
Beth is a married woman, and she has one child. She describes herself to be motivated. 

Beth operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of funds. 

Beth will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. Her business goal is to be successful within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be happy. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a married woman. She has three children with ages ranging from 2 years to 10 years. She describes herself to be ambitious. 

She operates a beauty salon where she offers beauty services. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a  populated area and her primary customers are daily customers. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate capital. 

She will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy more stock of beauty products for use in the salon. Her business goal is to have a stable business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have a stable business that will cater to family needs. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of beauty products for use in the salon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his son's school expenses.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 53-year-old man, married to Josephine, who adds additional income to support their family welfare. They are privileged to have two children.  Peter has been a carpenter for six years, earning an income of KES 15,000 at the end of every month.
   
He is now servicing his third loan of KES 45,000 and intends to use the entire amount to buy the following tools; circular saw, power drill, bubble level, and marking tools, which he majorly needs to facilitate his daily work.

Peter plans to use the anticipated income to buy a motorcycle to offer transport facilities as a secondary business and hopes to become a successful business man with a bright future.

loans.use: to buy carpentry tools: circular saw, power drill, bubble level, and marking tools.

loans.name: Rosana

texts.es: Rosana de 34 años de edad, habita con su cónyuge y sus 3 hijos en las edades de 6 a 16 años al suroccidente de la ciudad. Allí tiene una pequeña miscelanea que inició desde el año 1996 cuando observando las necesidades del sector percibió la inexistencia de un punto comercial que vendiera artículos como colonias, perfumería ropa y bisutería. Inició vinculándose a empresas que proveen revistas especializadas para que realicen su oferta y poco a poco con su capital propio, fue dotando su propia vivienda de un espacio para su negocio y fue comprando 1  vitrina con la que lograra exhibir los productos y vender mucho mas. Su tarea comercial la realiza todos los días desde las 9 de la mañana hasta las 8 dela noche y ofrece sus productos mediante las dos modalidades de crédito y de contado. Sus principales clientes están ubicados en el barrio donde habita y son sus principales promotores de su imagen comercial. Su meta mas adelante es ampliar el local donde está ubicada y lograr una educación de calidad para sus hijos. En la actualidad está aplicando  aun credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace la  Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante la cual comprará ropa femenina, e infantil colonias, con las cuales surtirá mucho mas su negocio para potencializar una mayor clientela y mejorar su negocio  con esta inversión.
texts.en:
Rosana is 34 years old, she lives with her partner and her 3 children, who are from 6 to 16 years old, in the southwest of the city. Here she has a small store that she started in 1996 when she saw the lack of a shop that sells things such as colognes, perfumes, clothes and costume jewellery.

She began linking with businesses that supply specialist magazines so that she could sell, and little by little with her own capital she equipped her own home with a space for her business and purchased a glass cabinet so she could display her products and sell much more.

She works every day from 9 in the morning until 8 in the evening. She offers her products both on credit and for cash payment. Her main customers are from the area where she lives and they are the main promoters of her commercial image. 

Her longer term goal is to increase the size of her business and give her children a quality education. 

She is applying for a kiva loan, her first from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, and will use it to buy women’s clothing and infant colognes. These will much improve the selection offered by her business, and this loan will allow for a greater customer base and improve her business.

loans.use: to buy women's clothes and infant colognes.

loans.name: Iris

texts.en:
Iris is 45 years old, married to Bahati and blessed with three children aged 17, 15 and three years. She has been running a salon for the last four years and earns a monthly income of KES.40,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES).
	 
Iris has applied for her second loan of 15,000 KES from VisionFund Kenya to buy more weaves, shampoos and other hair products.  She will use the anticipated profits to provide for her family's basic needs. She hopes to grow her business and open a bigger studio.

loans.use: to buy more weaves, shampoos and other hair products

loans.name: Trancy

texts.en:
Tracy is 18 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past two years, Tracy has been working hard to manage her food market, which sells fresh food. 

To help expand her business, Tracy has requested a loan of 550,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh food for sale, and will help Tracy to generate greater profits and pay for the house rent. Tracy hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Tracy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more fresh food for sale,

loans.name: Kasturi Group

texts.en:
Prabha, aged about 27 years, is the leader of the Kasturi group in J.K.Pur in the district of Rayagada, Odisha, India.  She has a small family comprising 4 members; herself, her husband, and also one son and one daughter, aged 5 and 8 respectively. The member standing first on the right with raised hand is Prabha. 

At present she is doing a rice business with her husband. They are procuring paddy in the harvesting season in bulk, processing it, and selling it. Thereby they earn a handful of money. Prabha’s husband is assisting her to run the business smoothly by purchasing paddy from different villages and processing it in the mill. At present her family income is INR 4,500 per month from the rice Business. She is a very active lady who wants some extra income out of her own efforts.

To improve her living conditions and to earn some extra income, she wants to avail a loan from Mahashakti.  From the loan amount, she will purchase huge quantities of paddy from the nearby villages and process it to avail a cash discount and also save transportation cost which she incurs frequently. She has a dream to increase her business and educate her children in a better school.

The other four members of her group are Sarita, Magmata, Sukanti, and Rukmini, each doing individual business.

loans.use: procure paddy for processing and sale

loans.name: Janma Bhumi Group

texts.en:
Suwartha is the leader of Janma Bhumi Group and lives in J.K.Pur in the district of Rayagada, Odisha, India. She is a married woman of 49 years. She has a small family comprising four members: herself, her husband, and also one son and one daughter aged 18 and 31 respectively. The member standing 2nd from left with raised hand is Suwartha. 

Like most families in the locality, she and her husband are running a grocery shop in J.K.Pur town. She sells rice, dal, tea, sugar, chocolate, etc., in her shop.  She is a very active lady who wants some extra income out of her own efforts. Suwartha’s husband is assisting her to run the business smoothly  by purchasing grocery items from the nearby town. At present her family income is INR 5,000 per month from the grocery shop, which is not sufficient to maintain her family. 

To improve her living conditions and to earn some extra income, she wants to avail a loan from Mahashakti.  From the loan amount, she will purchase grocery items in bulk quantity to avail a cash discount and also save transportation costs, which she incurs frequently. She has a dream to have a wholesale shop in the town and educate her children in a better college in the town.

The other three members of her group are doing individual business.

loans.use: purchase grocery items

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buy fabric and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Nicodemus

texts.en:
Nicodemus, a father of one, is a very passionate farmer based in Kisii, a rural town in Kenya known for banana and sugarcane growing. He has been practicing mixed farming for four years, and also tries his hand at small business ventures during low seasons. You will catch him selling milk and eggs from his home any day of the week if not working on his tea farm. Poor roads and lack of market are some of the biggest challenges crippling farmers in his village. 

To gain access to financial services at a low interest rate, Nicodemus joined Juhudi Kilimo. He seeks to improve his family's livelihood by being able to give his child a good quality education. With your help, Nicodemus hopes to acquire an additional good grade cow to increase his milk production and sales.

loans.use: To buy a quality cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her son's education.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase material for his welding workshop.

loans.name: Shitu

texts.en: Shitu remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Shitu, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Shitu  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Shitu. With this loan, Shitu is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Malam Surajo

texts.en: Malam Surajo is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Malam Surajo joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Aliyu, Bello, and  Shamsidin. Malam Surajo is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Malam Surajo will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Malam Surajo can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Malam Surajo is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home”. loans.name: Bushira's Group

texts.en:
Bushira's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Bushira is 16 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past one year, Bushira has been working hard to manage her carpentry business, which sells house furniture. 

To help expand her business, Bushira has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more timber for furniture, and will help Bushira to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young sister. Bushira hopes that in the future she will be able to start up another business. 

Bushira is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more timber for making furniture.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be optimistic. She operates a retail business where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of charcoal. Her business goal is to have a more profitable business within five years. She hopes that in the future she will have improved living standards. She will use the anticipated profits to purchase more products.

loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his sister's education.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 19 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past two years, Aisha has been working hard to manage her grocery business, which sells charcoal and vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more items for sale, and will help Aisha to generate greater profits and pay rent for the business. Aisha hopes that in the future, she will be able to start up a clothes business. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more items for sale.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es: Elizabeth tiene 34 años de edad y desarrolla la actividad de comerciante desde el año 2001, cuando al mudarse en un barrio del municipio de Soledad, percibió que tenia la oportunidad de vender en su propia casa, artículos necesarios, que sus vecinos debían comprar en el centro de la ciudad cercana y les salia mas costoso en tiempo y dinero, a ninguno se le había ocurrido tener un punto comercial y por esta razón Elizabeth dió inicio a  su idea, tomando sus ahorros para invertirlo en su meta inmediata de producir. Hoy vende en una pequeña miscelanea papaelería, accesorios femeninos, bisutería, artículos para el hogar y detalles para regalos., a crédito y de contado, entre su clientela conformada por vecinos del sector donde habita. Su meta mas adelante es abrir 2 locales mas en barrios contiguos en los que aun no hay este tipo de negocio y aumentar cada vez mas la calidad de vida de su familia. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará artículos de papelería, juguetearía, accesorios para el hogar, con ello mejorará el surtido de su local comercial y atraerá mucha mas clientela con la cual mejorará las condiciones de su negocio.
texts.en:
Elizabeth, age 34, has been working as a merchant since 2001.  When she moved to a neighborhood in the Soldedad municipality, she saw that she had the opportunity of selling at her own house.  She sells items that her neighbors need that they had to buy at the center of the nearby city.  This was more costly for them in time and money.  It had not occurred to anyone to have a commercial place in her neighborhood.  That is what gave start to Elizabeth’s idea.  She took her savings to invest in her immediate goal of carrying out her idea.

She now has a small business selling miscellaneous goods like stationery, women’s accessories, costume jewelry, household items, and gifts.  She sells on credit and for cash.  Her clientele is comprised of neighbors from the area where she lives.

Her goal for later is to open two more locations in adjacent neighborhoods where they still do not have this type of business.  Her goal is also to increase  her family’s quality of life more and more.

She is currently applying for a Kiva loan, her first loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  She will use the loan to buy stationery items, toys, and household accessories.  This will improve the stock in her business and attract a lot more customers.  By doing so her business conditions will improve.

loans.use: to buy stationery items, toys, and household accessories.

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick is a married man. He has one child. He describes himself to be focused. 

He operates a transport business, where he transports customers using his tuk tuk. He has been involved in this business for two years. His business is located in a vibrant location, and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the lack of capital. 

He will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy stock of groceries to expand his wife’s grocery business. 

His business goal is to own two tuk tuks within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will own a piece of land. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy stock of groceries to expand his wife's grocery business.
